messages.text: It should be pretty good for this. How many channels do you need? If it's something like 16 channels, then I'd recommend using an `SVector{16,T}` as the element type of your arrays and writing your algorithms for that datatype.

elements.text: It should be pretty good for this. How many channels do you need? If it's something like 16 channels, then I'd recommend using an
SVector{16,T}
as the element type of your arrays and writing your algorithms for that datatype.

messages.text:
Hi,

I would like to warp an image by the log-polar transform but I have troubles to make it work. Can someone give me a push please?

```using CoordinateTransformations, ImageTransformations
struct Retinotopy <: Transformation; end
struct InvRetinotopy <: Transformation; end
function (::Retinotopy)(x)
    length(x) == 2 || error("Polar transform takes a 2D coordinate")

    Polar(log(hypot(x[1], x[2])), atan(x[2], x[1]))
end

function (::InvRetinotopy)(x::Polar)
    s,c = sincos(x.Œ∏)
    SVector(exp(x.r) * c, exp(x.r) * s)
end
(t::InvRetinotopy)(x) = t(Polar(x[1], x[2]))
Base.inv(::Retinotopy) = InvRetinotopy()

tfm = Retinotopy()
imgw = warp(img, tfm);```

elements.text:
Hi,

I would like to warp an image by the log-polar transform but I have troubles to make it work. Can someone give me a push please?

using CoordinateTransformations, ImageTransformations
struct Retinotopy <: Transformation; end
struct InvRetinotopy <: Transformation; end
function (::Retinotopy)(x)
    length(x) == 2 || error("Polar transform takes a 2D coordinate")

    Polar(log(hypot(x[1], x[2])), atan(x[2], x[1]))
end

function (::InvRetinotopy)(x::Polar)
    s,c = sincos(x.Œ∏)
    SVector(exp(x.r) * c, exp(x.r) * s)
end
(t::InvRetinotopy)(x) = t(Polar(x[1], x[2]))
Base.inv(::Retinotopy) = InvRetinotopy()

tfm = Retinotopy()
imgw = warp(img, tfm);

messages.text: `ImageFeatures.jl` has the functions for feature detection and matching between features.  Is there a function of package for estimating the geometric transform, like MATLAB has the `estimageGeometricTransform2D` function.

function.

<@USU9FRPEU>, bug reports for `channelview` should go to ImageCore. But for me,
```julia> img = testimage("multi-channel-time-series.ome.tif")
‚îå Warning: ignored the empty prefix for '<http://www.openmicroscopy.org/Schemas/OME/2015-01>'; expected to be non-empty
‚îî @ EzXML ~/.julia/packages/EzXML/ZNwhK/src/xpath.jl:85
Gray ImageMeta with:
  data: 4-dimensional AxisArray{Gray{N0f8},4,...} with axes:
    :y, 1:167
    :x, 1:439
    :channel, [:C1, :C2, :C3]
    :time, 1:7
And data, a 167√ó439√ó3√ó7 reshape(reinterpret(Gray{N0f8}, ::Array{Int8, 6}), 167, 439, 3, 7) with eltype Gray{N0f8}
  properties:
    Description: 
    Elapsed_Times: Unitful.Quantity{Float64, ùêì, Unitful.FreeUnits{(s,), ùêì, nothing}}[NaN s NaN s ‚Ä¶ NaN s NaN s; NaN s NaN s ‚Ä¶ NaN s NaN s; NaN s NaN s ‚Ä¶ NaN s NaN s]

julia> channelview(img)
Normed ImageMeta with:
  data: 4-dimensional AxisArray{N0f8,4,...} with axes:
    :y, 1:167
    :x, 1:439
    :channel, [:C1, :C2, :C3]
    :time, 1:7
And data, a 167√ó439√ó3√ó7 reinterpret(reshape, N0f8, reshape(reinterpret(Gray{N0f8}, ::Array{Int8, 6}), 167, 439, 3, 7)) with eltype N0f8
  properties:
    Description: 
    Elapsed_Times: Unitful.Quantity{Float64, ùêì, Unitful.FreeUnits{(s,), ùêì, nothing}}[NaN s NaN s ‚Ä¶ NaN s NaN s; NaN s NaN s ‚Ä¶ NaN s NaN s; NaN s NaN s ‚Ä¶ NaN s NaN s]```
so please include `versioninfo` and package versions.

messages.text: I wrote a small reader package for Phantom high speed video .cine files, and I'm trying to figure out where it fits/which interfaces it should conform to before (/if) I register it

elements.text: I wrote a small reader package for Phantom high speed video .cine files, and I'm trying to figure out where it fits/which interfaces it should conform to before (/if) I register it

messages.text: ffmpeg (and thus VideoIO) supports .cine files, but downgrades them to a bit depth of 8 bits, while I want access to my camera's full 12 bit range. The high framerate also violates the real-time assumptions made by VideoIO (indexing by the time in seconds? I'm dealing with microseconds!), and the files can be many gigabytes, which makes it prohibitively expensive to load them in a non-streaming manner

elements.text: ffmpeg (and thus VideoIO) supports .cine files, but downgrades them to a bit depth of 8 bits, while I want access to my camera's full 12 bit range. The high framerate also violates the real-time assumptions made by VideoIO (indexing by the time in seconds? I'm dealing with microseconds!), and the files can be many gigabytes, which makes it prohibitively expensive to load them in a non-streaming manner
